It wasn't that I didn't like it, in fact, I love the taste of coffee and needed it to get through 18 hour work days, 7 days a week (shout out to all those working at the Big 4).  Nevertheless, I was able to make the successful transition to tea.

Then, one beautiful Sunday afternoon, I was introduced to Philz coffee.  It was like my mouth and body were reunited with a long lost lust.  The sweet aroma of the Great Philharmonic, the crisp taste of coffee that is brewed with filtered water, and the homey feel of a truly neighborhood gem, it took only one sip to bring me back to the world of coffee.  That cup could have easily been the best I have ever had.  Even though there are two other locations, I will always remember the Castro spot for popping my born-again coffee cherry.

Tip:
- This location has outdoor seating.  On a nice summer day in the city, grab a friend, chat with a date, or buy a paper, and enjoy a cup of joe for a perfect mid-afternoon.
author: Herman N.

description:
If this place was closer to me I would be getting coffee there everyday ESPECIALLY on my way to work. I would really get up on time just to get coffee from here. Whats also nice is that there is a description of all thier roasts for all the newbies.Turkish coffee, deelish!!! I like the dark roasts and love, love, love the mocha tesora. I dont need to add a single thing to this. Normally, if i go to Starbucks, or Peets or whatever place is closest to me, I have to add a little something. whether it be cream, sugar or what have you. Another cool thing about this place is that its soooo chill inside. None of that blue tooth wearin, Im playin video games, pretending to do homework on my laptop, tryina pick up on chicks type thing at Starbucks. Dont get me wrong, I like Starbucks but, I dont like to hang out there like that. 

Give it a try folks.
author: Trisha C.

description:
Philz is the best damn coffee in San Francisco. What an ingenious idea, and let's hope that Philz can weather out this recession by maintaining their great service. 

As you might have gathered by now, Philz makes one cup of coffee at a time, exactly as you want it. Select from a menu of 20 or so coffee blends. And don't forget to try the Turkish coffee! 

You don't really insert your own condiments, rather the barista does it for you. The staff are professional and engaging, and the owners even embrace Yelp on their website (and they respect the few bad reviews!)

The reason that this particular Castro location didn't get a top-notch rating from me is that this tiny space is just too small, slightly larger than a broom closet. (Ok, I'm exaggerating). The space is also attached to a crappy laundromat with suck service. Of course this has nothing to do with Philz, but considering that they previously had a corner location down the street, this is a step down.  

But congratulations on all the 5-star reviews Philz, you definitely deserve it!
author: Daniel C.

description:
Came here because my sister wanted to try it.
They really market on brewing "one cup at a time"...which in retrospect, is quite an advantage for ANY in the coffee business
Freshness is essential.

This is something that bigger coffee companies may have a harder time deploying, due to the fact that more locations mean a compromise in distribution time = less fresh.
Also, while many smaller coffee shop roast freshly, and grind daily, they lack in BEAN QUALITY...simply the soul and the art of the coffee.

I tried their HOUSE blend...my analysis:
It was a blend of low-grade Latin American robusta beans, with high quality arabica African beans, defining its blueberry notes, in aroma and taste profile.  It also had unmistakable nutty notes.
It could also be entirely Latin American, as some private estates are known to produce the African-signature berry notes.
Their brewing method was a paper-filter single brewer.

Conclusion:
1 star for freshness
1 star for AWESOME customer service
Another star for the quaint atmosphere (i.e. fedora hats on sale)

Half-way there using the arabica beans, but thumbs down for the robusta infiltration...it dilutes the premium coffee experience.
author: Jay M.

description: Tasty coffee, great service, friendly staff, if i can give 10 stars I would!  The pastries are amazing!!!!!!! I love Philz.
author: Mimi S.

description:
Oh man I love Philz.  All the blends, the little touches they add to each cup and mostly the caffeine high that follows.

love it.
author: Chris D.

description:
What an experience! My dear friend (cbp) and I, with full tummies from our fantastic lunch at blue, decided that we needed a caffeine high to continue our day. 

It's a family run spot that takes pride in their work, you can tell... the son (with the pretty eyes) is the master of coffee-creation at this small but cozy place. Jacob (I think?) made me a coffee beverage that was out of this world. 

THEY are opening another Philz near PacBell BallPark, he said!!!
author: M'ia K.

description:
It's not coffee. It's a tongue-gasm. Seriously it's stupid how good this place is. I don't know what they do behind the counter there (I'm short and I can't see over it. Fuck you.) but when they hand you your cup and you take a sip it's like drinking a (heavily) caffeinated cloud. 

Few things in this world have the power to surprise me more than once. Philz' ability to regularly churn out obnoxiously delicious coffee is one of them.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Best coffee in the Castro. I walk past at least five other places to get here. 

When you order each cup is made one at a time, with a little bit of flair. The water is poured through a standard filter, but for some reason they really emphasize the pouring. You will often see them bring the hot water pot above eye level. 

If you  take cream and sugar, they add it for you. It reminds me of Turkish coffee, or Dunkin Donuts. Sweetness has levels, and cream seems to be binary. Also, the cream is REAL cream, heavy, thick, and unhealthy. They shake it a bit to build up a little froth, and it's super tasty.

 Phil works out of this shop often, and if he isn't there his son is. They are both interesting guys, and make great cups of coffee. At 3 bucks a cup it can feel pricy, but if you're used to buying lattes everyday its not so bad.
author: Geoffrey P.

description:
When you step into Philz, you not only step into the shop, but you step into both the past AND THE FUTURE of the coffee enterprise dynasty.  You are stricken by how comforting the place feels, and how, more or less, this must have been what cafes were like two-hundred years ago.  But you also acknowledge that to remain true to the core beliefs of the coffee monarchy is to surge screaming into the future.  If other coffee shops had brains as this coffee shop, the world would be a more delicious place.

  Speaking of delicious places, I am grateful for the coffee cup that holds Philz Holy Nectar Brew (it isn't the name of any coffees he has available for sale, it's just how I feel someone should describe his coffee).  This cup is as important to me as the bag containing donor's blood is to the unfortunate man in need of a transfusion.  This cup makes it possible for me to take part in Philz world, a world I wish I could remain in for all time.

  Fortunately Philz world is populated with genuine, good-natured people, the sort of people that seem to be in danger of extinction.  People who care, people who are human being and understand that they are dealing with human beings, and treat these humans as such.  It's a concept lost on many coffee-related businesspeople, which is no less shameful than nursing homes staffed with angry abusive nurses.

  But negativity does not belong in this review because none can be found at Philz.  The crux of the positive vibrations is the coffee.  It's difficult to describe this coffee in words, for words are much too crude a medium in which to render sentiment of this magnitude.  Words would defile the beauty of what I mean to say when I say I love Philz Coffee more than any other coffee I've let into my body.  Philz Coffee is so good it's like loving a song so much you can't listen to it because it breaks your heart.  Philz Coffee is being alive knowing that one day you will die.

  Get the large, get a seat, and get living.
author: Ignacio N.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker, so my modus operandi today is stealing the opinions of others. This was the first place my dad picked out when he came to help me move in. Roommate Johnny loves this place, which is what brought me here despite my alack of coffee drinking: this is one of the fine establishments to which we brought our visiting friend.  And I'm sure (former) roommate Rishi, the most dedicated coffee drinker I know, would appreciate this place, if only because it would remind him of Phil Leotardo. 

On the other hand, roommate Dan validly points out this place is a bit on the expensive side: $3 for a small, and it specializes in coffee as opposed to the espresso that he and I prefer.

As for me?  I had a mocha, and while for most things I prefer my chocolate-coffee concoctions to be chocolate with a hint of espresso -- like, say, gelato -- I'm not one to try a place's coffee by having hot chocolate.  The barista asked how sweet, I said not very, and it came out just right.
author: Jack S.

description:
I am definitely a fan of Philz. They have an expansive menu of coffees, so much that it would take you about a month of Philz everyday just to try them all.

It's a little intimidating to know which one to order, but the Barista guy was super suggestive in picking me out a delicious coffee. He recommended the Philtered Soul, the names are pretty clever, and it was a pretty decent cup of coffee. You would expect because they brew each cup individually, so it takes about 5 minutes to get your coffee after you already ordered. There was also a long line, so if you're in a hurry, and you're not there for the Philz experience, then it's probably not the coffee shop for you.

I almost forgot to mention, they have a laundromat in the back called Sit & Spin. It's ingenious really. Order really great coffee while you do your laundry. Every laundromat should have something like this!
author: Xavier G.

description:
First of all, all of the Philz Coffee locations that I have gone to have wonderful baristas. They are super nice and are very knowledgeable about their coffee as well as how to get the best coffee for each customer :)

I just visited the Castro location and they were fabulous. I ordered a Mocha Tornero (or something like that). It was delicious and just enough caffeine for me (coffee goes a long long way for me).
author: AnneMarie A.

description:
Finally a coffee place in California that puts the cream and sugar in for you!  Imagine how much you're saving the environment by not using the plastic/wooden stirrers.  

When they do add the cream in for you, they shake it and pour it in as the coffee is dripping into your cup.  This makes for one incredibly  creamy coffee.  

I make my own coffee during the week because I'm so cheap but I'll splurge on Sat/Sun just to have this coffee.  This is the best coffee I've ever had.  The people are also really nice.  

The only beef is that they need better pastries....
author: Tom K.

description:
There is nothing else in the City like Philz one-cup-at-a-time coffee.  Imagine my surprise when I went down to the location on 18th and Noe this morning to find, like yelposity o., that it was no longer Philz Coffee!?

Ok, it was kind of like Philz, but the selection of coffees was much smaller and it just didn't feel like Philz.  I called the original Philz on 24th and Folsom to see what was up, and was told that Phil and his partner at the Castro location parted ways.

Too bad.  It looks like I'm back to getting my java fix at Martha Bros on 24th, and when I'm in the 'hood, the original Philz on 24th.
author: Daniel S.

description: Great location just off the busy Castro St, a bit into the residential area. This Philz is just like any other Philz. What did you expect?
author: Ray C.

description: On perhaps the worst day of my life, the best cup of coffee I've ever had.
author: dan s.

description: Euphoria at its climax for the holy grail seeker of coffee. This is one more element of "american beauty" Lester Burnham could've have left the world with seconds before his imminent death. Phil, the OG of real San Franciscan coffee, can enlighten you with the simple pleasure and kind of happiness any Californian should pursue in place of psychotropics that frequent the passageways to our souls. Appreciate the hand-brewing process and undivided attention that goes into each and every cup. Even at 1400 hours, one can be able to rise and shine all over again, but with more life.
author: Harper L.

description: This is one of the smaller Philz that I have visited with only two baristas. Coffee as always was superb and they Always hire friendly warm people. Tried the philharmonic which like every other coffee there was fantastic
author: Christopher W.

description: Hands down the best coffee in the city.  Really no debate about that as far as I am concerned.  On top of that the staff is not only knowledgeable, but genuinely love coffee and care about making sure that you get the perfect cup of coffee every time.
author: Erin B.

description:
hate to be a pooper, but i don't love philz. the coffee doesn't taste as good as other drip to order places, and i really don't like the fact that they add your cream and sugar for you (why can't i do it myself?). 

having said that, i thought it was cool they had a huge coffee selection (like 20 different roasts to choose from).  it's got a more homey / less hipster feel than the other sf coffee roasteries but if you're looking for serious coffee with a more refined taste, you probably won't like this.
author: Jill L.

description:
I had no idea coffee could be this good. Philz has made me a total Starbucks hater. Starbucks is not coffee, it's crap. PHILZ IS WHAT COFFEE SHOULD BE. The fact that I love their almond pastries like no other also makes me love Philz. In what state can you marry a cafe? I may have to move to that state.

They treat coffee like people up in Napa treat wine. Such precision, such gratitude of each note and undertone and flavor. Light, medium, and dark roasts... about, what, 15 of each?

Philharmonic is my baby. I ask for it without the cardamom, and without the mint. It's too tea-like with them.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I want to hate my old housemate for knowing about Phil'z the entire time we lived together in the city and never suggesting that we go there until today when I was visiting her.  But it's hard to hate someone after they've introduced you to steaming hot sex in a cup, so we've made amends.  

Like all of my reviews involving coffee I'll start by saying that I normally drink my coffee plain.  I've even made a recent move from putting cream in my coffee to drinking it black.  Anything other than simple drip has to be pretty special for me to be interested in drinking it.  

While I don't think I'd drink Phil'z on a daily basis (it's very creamy and rich), the Philharmonic hit the spot on an icy cold San Francisco day.  I've been feeling a little bah humbug about the holidays, but Christmas shopping was made much more tolerable by my cup of spicy, cardamon infused coffee.  Coffee doesn't normally seem like a special treat to me (it's more like my lifeblood), but Phil'z has that special glow about it.
author: Katie S.

description: A spectacular cup of coffee. It takes a bit longer than other shops that brew gallons at a time but oh so worth it! The blends are very distinctive and the baristas will help you select a favorite from their extensive list. Big Philharmonic fan myself. They cream and sugar the coffee for you so tell them light or heavy if you want less or more sweet or creamy.
author: Richard J.

description:
Had my first Philz experience today. I realized I'm only a mile away from the new Castro location so I took a stroll over this morning. The shop is somewhat small with a few tables outside - not exactly the coziest cafe of all time. But honestly I'm not the hang out in the coffee shop kind of guy so let's get down to business here and discuss Philz coveted coffee.

The two employees working there were extremely helpful. I let them know it was my first time and explained that I am a fan of dark roasts - I drink Columbians and French roasts all the time. They suggested the Jacob's Wonderbar Brew which is named after Philz son and although I usually don't take cream in my coffee I opted for it after the employees insisted I give it a try. The great thing about Philz is that they prepare each cup to order. The brew came out incredibly creamy with a good hint of chocolate and subtle bitterness. I'd actually prefer a much more acidic and bitter roast - but I have a feeling I'm going to be back again and again to try everything they've got!
author: Ben K.

description:
so, about five minutes ago, I was just sitting in the coffee shop waiting for my laundry to finish (which many if not all people do) and I was asked to leave and proceed to the "laundry waiting area" because I was using their wi-fi (which I have saved on my computer from previous times).  i'm five feet away, not in the coffee shop boundaries, still using their wi-fi.  from his stern rudeness, i was surprised he did not take my computer away and force me to log off.  If wi-fi is free for customers (which I was once one)  why is there a conflict of interest if I sit at their vacant (among many) tables or on the street

I would behoove managers and restaurant owners to convey a more civil demeanor towards customers or potential customers due to the fast exchange of information and how quickly a spot can go sour due to customer complaints.  

A customer cannot be judged by their clothes and being a coffee hipster that I am.  They lost weekly visits and plenty of recommendations.  i strongly recommend not frequenting this rude establishment.  customer service is obviously not their priority.  the employee could have asked me nicely, however, he forcefully kicked me and another individual out. that does not customer service make.
author: Boho H.

description:
Love Philz. I've been drinking good coffee ever since I've moved out here, but Philz might be the pick of the litter.

If you haven't gone, do.

The price range is high for coffee--expensive treat, but worth it.
author: Inga B.

description:
I've heard the story about Phil and his son, with their two locations and their loyal followers, so I was intrigued.

The first option on the menu was a Turkish coffee ($2.50), so I went for that. I was confused, however, when the guy (an older man) asked me if I wanted sugar in the coffee. Well, of course! What is Turkish coffee without lots of sugar?

Then he went back to work, but soon stopped and asked me if I wanted cream. In Turkish coffee? WTF? Declined. He finally handed over my "Turkish coffee", complete with some mint leaves floating on top.

Ok, I get it. This is not your authentic, boiled thrice in a cezve, thick as sludge on the bottom, turn the cup and read your fortune type of Turkish coffee. This is some new California spin. Fine, whatever, I'll try it.

And I say "meh". The drink itself wasn't bad, but definitely it wasn't Turkish coffee, so don't call it that. I feel duped.

On the other hand, the shop had a happy crowd inside, and it was a lot of fun to sit outside and watch people walking their dogs and the dogs interacting with each other. It had a nice, indie neighborhood cafe kind of feel, and that I appreciate. If I'm ever back again, I'll try a normal cup of black coffee. I won't be getting the "Turkish coffee" again.
author: John C.

description:
I went into Philz today for the first time. I was slightly wary, as I almost always drink espresso drinks to avoid the unfortunate effect coffee seems to have on my stomach. 

I expressed my concerns to the super friendly barista, who explained that Philz coffees have low acidity and that I wouldn't have to worry. I wanted an iced drink, so I got the "Ecstatic Iced Coffee," which is an iced blend of all their roasts. It was delicious with exactly the right amount of cream and sugar and had excellent flavor. It would be a little pricy to make this my daily coffee, but I really enjoyed my experience and appreciated the kind and patient service. I will be back (but just once in a while!).
author: Crystal F.

description: The best coffee in town, without a doubt.  I actually get excited thinking about Philz the night before I get to go there between appointments.  Great service and staff.  Couldn't recommend them enough.  Love this place.  Large variety of roasts with great descriptions to satisfy anybody's tastes for light, medium, or darks.
author: Joe F.

description: This seems to be the quickest philz, maybe that's because everyone is walking somewhere and there's not much room to sit down. I myself only hop in here on my bike or when I can find a spot right on 18th street. As always Philz has the best coffee in SF and they aren't snobs about it - if they see someone struggling with the menu of 30+ blends of coffee they help them out and start them off with a tesora. I'll stick with my silken splendor, thank you very much.
author: Heshy F.

description: Great spot.  We had the Philharmonic and the Ether, both black.  Coffee was excellent and a great spot to sit outside.
author: Dan W.

description:
Amazing coffee! Each cup brewed individually.  You pick your desired coffee from the menu and they make your cup right there and then. It's such an amazing experience to know that you are drinking something that was specially made for you. That the time and effort really shows in the taste and pride of the people behind the counter. 

Little note:  Not to say that I don't love this place and try to make the three blocks trek to it as much as I can but....sometimes the Chai varies from person to person. The first time I had a Chai latte here I thought my head was going to explode it was so amazing. The second time the same person did not make it as brilliantly. But when you touch the sun your first time around it could be hard to do it again. I have not experienced inconsistancies with the coffee and have been satisfied everytime I get it.

Overall, Philz reignited my love of really great handcrafted coffees. Thank you!
author: Sarah K.

description:
This is by far the best coffee I have had in SF so far... quite possibly my life.  I will only give it four stars however because I usually order my coffee with splenda and fat free milk, but at philz was ordered by Phil's son that I had to trust him and have the best cup of coffee I have ever had, ever.  So I trusted him, and he poured a ton of heavy cream into the coffee.  So... of course it was delicious... heavy cream makes everything better.

On another trip I had the Mocha... and it was perfect, but he got to me... and I ordered with full fat cream.  I don't know if I can ever have Philz coffee with fat free milk... it just might be a sacrilege.
author: kim r.

description:
Okay... I feel that Philz has plenty of yelp attention... but recently there has been some debate as to whether Blue Bottle Coffee or Philz is better. I am going to "throw my two cents in" as to this challenge. 

I truly believe that as far as a straight cup of coffee is concerned, Philz has Blue Bottle beat. That being said, if you're one whom likes a good Latte, I think Blue Bottle has Philz beat. There you have it.... mi dos centavos.
author: Tom C.

description:
Mocha Tesora.  Wow.  Wow....

I thought I had pretty much decided Peet's Major D was the best coffee possible - even after trying coffees in over 30 countries. But Philz is something different. They do use spices (cocoa, cardomon) but I'm fine with that.

So I had heard the buzz about Philz while I was living in Wellington, NZ, and was anxious to try it after coming back.

Sister and I went.  I asked them for something "full-bodied, not acidic, preferably with pacific regional coffees, and dark as can be".  Mocha Tesora was their response and it was beautiful.  

My sister got the decaf though...which I thought was close to undrinkable, though she liked it.

Stick with the small size.  They use three times the "normal" amount of coffee and its consistency is closer to turkish than to drip.  A large may make you jittery or not sleep (as it did to me) but I see it as a limitation of our human bodies and not Philz coffee. :)
author: Matthew B.

description: This is how much I love Philz...I wake up in the morning, eat breakfast, drive from the sunset to the Castro to grab a small Tesora...EVERYDAY!!
author: nabil s.

description:
Their Philharmonic is thus far my absolute favorite coffee. I even buy their expensive beans so I can drink it at home. 
As a coffee maker they're fantastic, but as a place to sit and drink my coffee, medium low.  The store is very small, and the music is too loud for me.
author: Sara L.

description:
Philz brews up some of the freshest, tastiest, most delicately nuanced coffee I've ever sampled, equally appealing to both the mocha/latte crowd and the coffee purists alike.  

The service is spot-on as well.  When my friends and I told the barista we were first-timers, he smiled and said, "Come here.  I'll make something good for you," as though he were about to create custom works of art for each of us.

Though there are a few small tables, I probably wouldn't hang out here.  Nearby Dolores Park, however, is the perfect place to take in some sunshine and enjoy a delicious drink from Philz.
author: Karin H.

description:
Coffee Connoisseurs listen up! Have you imagined a coffee house where they hand pick and concoct your drink based on your unique taste? Well, here it is!

Philz is refreshingly unique and strives to ensure that you love what ever they make you. Seriously, they actually ask, how do you like your drink? It kind of reminded me of going wine tasting. They ask you, what do you usually drink? And then they offer their suggestion.

I went in and told them that I usually get lattes, so the barista said try #19. It was the smoothest espresso I've ever had.

Also, their mojito is a must try if you like mint.  It's a refreshing iced coffee with REAL mint, not a mint "flavored" syrup.

This place is about as authentic and fresh as it gets.
author: Lauren T.

description:
ugh.

music:  grating, tedious, aharmonic - and from me that's saying a lot since i like tom waits, black flag, nin, and manson

tea: CLEAN THE FUCKING INFUSERS!!!  the chai my friend got was too weak, but it was strong enough to flavor my black tea right after because they didn't clean the infuser.  do you know how nasty a weak cardamon flavor is in tea?  ugh!!!

service:  ok considering they are trying to be friendly and courteous, even if they have no clue about being coffee or tea barristas.

wireless:  free and fast

convenience:  how cool is it to have coffee/tea while doing laundry?  very!

final comment:  get stuff here if you're lazy and doing laundry.  go down the street or a few blocks over for better coffee or tea.
author: Peter K.

description: This was my second stop at Philz ever and was definitely yummy!! Was going to get the iced mint mojito, but decided for a decaf coffee instead.  I don't think you can go wrong with their drinks! Yum!!
author: Tara R.

description:
So, the result of having become a weekend squatter at Ritual is that I almost never drink cappuccino anywhere else.  

However, after a coffee-less meal at Samovar (sacrilege, a brunch without coffee), I rushed over to Philz's and immediately ordered a double cappuccino.

Ritual: is it cheating? I am sorry, but Philz's cappuccino is so good.  A hint of chocolate, the creamiest foam.  Delightful.  Almost a dessert cappuccino.

And the divine smell of roasted coffee beans in the place.  They need to bottle it into a perfume. 

I will be back soon for more. And then, who knows, I might have to divide my weekend cappuccinos  between Philz and Ritual.
author: Sooj O.

description:
it was pretty good coffee, but there was this lingering "bite" on my tongue and the back of my throat that kinda ruined the experience for me.  The coffee I had was some arabica "blend"...

anywhoo.... i enjoyed the coffee and it gave me the caffeine kick I needed on a Sunday morning.  I was not floored or awed by the experience.

(  |  )

side note: I just received a PM from my brother (http://dorianjay.yelp.com), who is a coffee connoisseur, and told me that my review did not make sense at all.  I am a TTH (trying too hard) wannabe coffee esssferrt.
author: Grace M.

description:
I like to go here before I hit Dolores Park. It's the perfect combo on a nice sunny weather. The coffee is made one cup at a time so don't complain if you have to wait! 

The ice coffee hands down the best ice coffee I've ever had in my entire life! They will make the coffee as you like it. Bittersweet, sweet, or just plain bitter =D

Yes, get off the couch you lazy ass and go to Philz now!!
author: Perry S.

description:
Cheap, non-snobby, great staff that is friendly and knowledgeable without being too obnoxiously perky. I'm so glad this place is so close to work. 

Now, I must say that I don't drink coffee. I went in there for a green tea- which they totally personalized with fresh mint leaves and honey. However there are TONS of coffee options, different beans not just different ingredients.

I must stress: This place is VERY inexpensive, for great cups and coffee by the pound. Evil Starbucks is closer to Castro St, but walk further down 18th and you'll fall in love with Philz!
author: Halley B.

description: I really like Phil'z. When I go, I get the iced coffee "Phil'z way," which is lightly sweetened with a little cream. There are two locations nearby me, so it's really convenient!
author: Nicole W.

description: I came here 2 or 3 times and was well received up until today where the baristas were 2 really unfriendly girls! They were either bored or were both in a bad mood. I spent about 5 min there, time to order and wait for my drink. I didn't see any smile on their arrogant face and the worst came when I paid for my drink: I give the lady the money and I was waiting for my change which she spontaneously put it in the Tip jar, without even giving it back to me first. WTF!? If it's because I have a European accent and that she assumed I wouldn't leave any tip, that is just the rudest thing ever! I was speechless...
author: Flo L.

description:
Certainly some of the best coffee I've ever had!

A gem of a small shop, Philz is serving up some single-cup brew that makes my taste buds tingle. That's right, one cup at a time, each one freshly brewed, just for your order. Now, it's dificult to describe, but the coffee is strong tasting, but rounded; sweet, yet powerful. I get the Mocha Tesora, but really, everything from Philz is genuine high quality. 

One star off (really only .5) for inconsistency in the way their cup is served. Sometimes it comes with fresh spearmint leaves (FIVE STARS!), and sometimes it doesn't. I know it's a small thing, but it's the little touches that really raise the bar.
author: Shannon F.

description:
Update: Best Baklava in town, even though they are from a whole sale place, Oasis in Belmont. Get them with your coffee, seriously. So flaky, and nutty and sweet. No sogginess at all. 

Best coffee in town. 
They have about 20+ different roasts that I never get tired trying new things. The girl who works there is super nice and very good with recommendations. Love her. The guy who mixed different beans according to my weird description of "in mood for" is awesome too. My favorite is the "Silken Splendor" with some freshly minced mint leaves. Sooooo smooth yest rich. The Philharmonic is very nice too.

My friend who doesn't drink coffee got the Istanbul treat, which is some kind of oriental flavored tea. Very yummy with the mint leaves. Oh and don't turn down the honey and cream. Because the tea itself has a hint of honey so it goes extremely well with the honey as sweetener. Yummmm!! 

Why go to Blue bottle when you could park (during off peak hours) and not stand in line for long for your cup of elisir?
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Good evening. My name is Gwen and I have turned from being an ice cream-holic to a coffee-holic. My coffee-holism started on a sunny weekday morning in the summer (*gasp* already a surprise that there's sun in San Francisco during the summer) when I had to take up early to drive my my parent somewhere. On my way back, I stopped into Philz Coffee shop in the Castro after hearing rave reviews from two people about the coffee. Playing it safe (because I don't take risks when it comes to food, just life), I ordered the Mocha Tesora thinking that it's hard to get coffee+chocolate wrong. I was sent into euphoria with the perfect blend of coffee, chocolate, and cream; not too sweet (i.e., hear that Starbucks), not too watery (pay attention Tully's), and not too bitter (i.e., Blue Bottle, Four Barrell). Since then I have been back almost every day, including weekends. Sometimes I even come twice. I drive all the way from my home to the 24th location and then double back to work in the morning so that I can get my Philz fix. Philz Coffee has taken over my bank account and my morning and afternoon life. Please Coffee-holics anonymous, let's help cure this addiction one cup at a time. 

The logistics: Street parking in this location is easier than in the SOMA and 24th Street stores. The downside is that this shop is smaller (only 2 counters to brew "One cup at a time") so the wait's longer.
author: Gwen L.

description:
I walked into this tiny shop, after getting a recommendation from a good friend to come here. People sat around using their computers at little cafe tables, and the door was open, letting in the breeze off of this quiet street off of the Castro. 

The man behind the counter welcomed me, and asked, "Hi, what kind of coffee do you want?" Now I am no coffee connoisseur. I drink mostly vanilla lattes or white chocolate mochas... so I replied, "well, I don't know." And he said, "Well, do you like light, medium, or dark beans?" I had no idea how to answer this question, so I just said, "Well, I like my coffee sweet, and with soy." Instead of giving me a hard time about not being a coffee drinker, he replied, "Ok. I'll make you a mocha." And he proceeded to make a homemade mocha right there on the spot. He had me try it after another couple min, and in its steamy, frothy sweetness, it was the best goddamn mocha I've ever tried. EVER. 

And that's coming from me- someone who doesn't know much about coffee. If I could tell that it was somehow better than other places, that's saying a lot. And if you ARE a coffee drinker, I am imagining the coffee must be pretty damn good. They customize your beans (light, medium, or dark) and make a billion (seemingly) different specialty drinks, but I'm sure they could also make a drink to order. The person behind the counter also had me try the drink at the end, to make sure I liked it, so he could adjust it if needbe. So. For coffee drinkers of any experience and taste, come to Philz for a glorified coffee-drinking experience.
author: Anna K.

description: This is my top 3 favorite coffee spots in the city, if you want variety come here!  Excellent fusion drinks and great staff.  Try the iced ginger snaps coffee or the iced mojito coffee, amazing!
author: David K.

description: I dare anyone to do a blind taste test and not choose  Philz as the best cup of coffee going.  It is unquestionably the best coffee in town.  So, why the four stars?  The price.  Four bucks for a cup of coffee is a lot!  Yes, its worth it, but it still is expensive . . .  Trust me though, if I were rich, I would have a Philz every day!
author: D H.

description:
All talk and no coffee.

I don't know what the deal is.  It's mediocre coffee with a load of cream and a load of sugar.  Not only that, they have no idea what "Just a tiny tiny tiny bit of cream and sugar" means.  So, If I go now, which is only if I'm a rush, and I don't have time to go anywhere else, I'll go.  And this is when you realize why they put so much crap in the coffee - so you can't actually taste the coffee.

That said, it's free wifi, and kind of a cool gimmick.  But, it should be called Philz caffeinated cream and sugar.  And, Uh, I don't know.  And, WTF.  Philz?  Is he trying to bring in the ghetto crowd?  I'm still not bringing in my homeboyZ.  Unless his name is actually Philz.  Then I feel like an ass.
author: masa s.

description: The philharmonic is so delicious that my boyfriend and I have been day dreaming about it for the last year we have been living out of State.  I am so happy to be back and gnawing on my complimentary mint flourish.
author: Cork C.

description:
Coffee. Liquor of the gods. Earthly Morning Bean of heavenly descent. I love you, coffee.

I stopped here one morning with a friend after a long hard night of boozing. Seriously, I thought I liked my coffee strong and plentiful - but after ordering a large turkish brewed medium roast (roasted and brewed to perfection, by the way), I understand that I've been drinking only moderately strong coffee. Pete's you've been one upped.

Warning: The coffee here is so strong that if not careful,  your brain will sparkle and crack and come roaring to life, only to come spiraling down with a fizzle and pop that will inspire the requisite and immediate trip to the bathroom followed by a despondent feeling of what just happened? What was I supposed to be doing today?.  

Philz makes one of the best cups of coffee in the city - hands down, just be aware what you are getting yourself into. One cup really is enough here - I believe the reason for my crash had to do with the fact that I had already had a bit of coffee that morning....
author: Frank Y.

description:
Don't ever claim that you've had a good cup of coffee around me or I will drag your ass to PHILZ whether you like it or not! This coffee is the best in the city and probably the world. With heavy whipping cream, brown sugar, a touch of cardamom, and a fresh mint leaf, BOOM! You have a cup of the bestest shit eva. There's also some secret ingredient they won't tell you about in the cream, but who the hell cares, it's too good to be true. Jacob, Philz son, is the shit. He's always warm and friendly and I swear if the coffee wasn't so good I'd still go just to shoot the shit with his funny ass. WE LOVE YOU PHILZ!!! 

PS. The Mission one is good too, but I never go there anymore...
author: Robin B.

description:
The people who work at Philz are so friendly sometimes I feel like I am back in Iowa when I go there to get my coffee. Then, I remember that this place is attached to a laundromat called "Sit and Spin", and I am jolted from my Midwestern reverie and land securely back in the Castro. Then I taste the coffee, and I don't care where I am, I just don't want to leave. 

The coffee at Philz is far more addictive than the caffeine it contains. This is the tastiest coffee I have ever had. Yes, I am going to say it- better than Blue Bottle coffee. 

There are a ton of different varieties and if you're not sure what you want the charismatic sweetheart working behind the counter will guide you to something fabulous. I am partial to the "So Good" coffee, which more than lives up to its name. Coffee is served with a sprig of mint, which smooths the acidity and adds to the overall deliciousness. 

Also, they have huge samples of pastry and this weekend there were trays of free baklava both days. The baklava was great, and my companion and I split a piece of raspberry bread there Saturday which was also really yummy.

Needless to say, I am already planning my next trip to Philz..
author: Angie R.

description: Stopped by here today with a friend, and when the barista found out only  my friend was buying a drink, he offered me a free iced coffee! Yay! And it was very good iced coffee, too.
author: Cattie P.

description: They make every drink to order so it'll take a little longer than a Starbucks but totally worth it. It's part of a laundromat combo in Castro so if you're looking for PhilZ be on the watch out for that. The place had constant customers and prices were decent. Will be back!
author: Cindy T.

description:
LOVE the coffee. however, the service...not so much. considering the experience i'll share below i would only give philz three stars, but the coffee is just that good! 

this pissed me off: i come in to order and place my thorough order (answering all the questions they have for each cup) and moments later, a regular comes in, and as the guy is busy preparing our coffees, he chats up his regular. finishing, he gives the regular who came well after me his coffee and then asks me what i wanted again. wtf?! 

note to philz servers: don't ask what a customer wants, serve a regular AFTER the order, and then have the ballz to ask me what i wanted again. i don't care how good the coffee is, if the service sucks, i won't be back.
author: Torrpedo T.

description: This place hands down makes the best coffee I have ever had.  I am a coffee drinker and I really like discovering a good cup of Joe. When I was here I felt like something cold and sweet so I ordered an iced mocha and my oh my was I in heaven! The mocha was smooth and the coffee flavor came through beautifully.  I hate it when I order a mocha somewhere and all I taste is sugar and bad chocolate flavoring.  But no, not Philz, Philz does it right, oh-so-absolutely right.  I enjoyed my large mocha so much that I went back right after I ordered my first cup and ordered another.  I didn't care that it was approaching 5pm, this stuff was worth it!   So, yeah I had a hard time falling asleep and I was roaming the streets of S.F. until 11pm, and I was still 40 minutes away from home- but it was worth it!
author: K. R.

description:
I have easily become a Philz-head for my weekend coffee. Coffee served with kindness is the way to go. And while they don't scribble your name on your coffee cup like some OTHER places do, you still feel like they made your coffee especially for you. 

My favorite blend? Hands down, the Mocha Tesora. Delicious coffee with cocoa flavor.

While there are other locations, this one is cozy, convenient and my favorite. :)
author: Bryan B.

description:
I was curious about this place since they market themselves as the best coffee and hand made. I thought that was old school to make coffee by hand in the 20 century. They cannot be making that many cups of coffee if they were making each cup by hand. That is a lot of work out. 

The coffee was good but I am not sure if it is the best. I enjoyed sitting at the outside area. It was relaxing and not noisy. I will come back if I am in the neighborhood.
author: Ervinna L.

description: awesome cups; perfect temperature (no singed tongues), helpful staff that who know their coffee and just want to cater it perfectly to your order. Jacob's - extra sweet. GO!
author: Albert V V.

description: Went there after a Giants game to get  a hot cup of coffee. First time there. The guy who helped us was super friendly and attentive. The coffee shop is small but has both indoor and outdoor seating. It is amusingly attached to a laundromat/cleaners of some sort. Anywho, I ordered a cup of Ether, which by name, doesn't sound good for my health. "Cream or sugar?"...Nah, black is fine. "You sure?"...I should have took that as a warning. That was one of the strongest cups of coffee I have had in a long time.  Sad to say it suppressed my appetite so much I had to skip dinner. So no thanks on the Ether roast, because I would rather stuff my face.
author: Can L.

description: WOW! Just perfect! Great coffee, great service with friendly smiles, never been so welcomed to a coffe shop before. They always ask if it's to my liking. The Best!
author: Kenneth N.

description: Yeah, I'm finally on the philztrain! I am far from a coffee snob, but i appreciate a good cup and philz is better than good. My favorite is the So goooooood. But i've tasted a few other's and all are equally aromatic and tasty. I wish i had one closer to visit to get more familiar with but then again it's kinda nice to keep to my special sunday cup of coffee to look forward to. yum!
author: Audrey V.

description:
Consistently GOOD coffee. 

I'm a Blue Bottle girl but when closer to Dolores Park/Mission/Castro/Noe a nice cup-o-Philz makes me go Ahhhhhh. 

Good to the last drop.
author: Abby W.

description:
I'm from Portland where we are raised on coffee not milk, so the lack of decent coffee was one of the downsides of coming to SF.  Not long after moving here and settling in Noe Valley I decided one breezy day to walk home from an appointment in SOMA, and during my confused walk home the weather turned NASTY on me.  As the pouring rain turned to ping pong hail I sought some place of refuge to wait out the storm, and came across a little coffee shop that served my purpose.  

I walked in and approached a man at the counter and said "Uh- just a regular cup of coffee is fine".  The man looked at me and said "You ever had my coffee before?" I shook my head no.  "I will make you the best cup of coffee you have ever had." Then he did.  In one cup Phil made me a customer for life.
author: Dina A.

description:
I love Philz coffee whether it's in the Castro, SOMA or the Mission. The ordering is a bit chaotic sometimes but for me that adds to the overall feel. If your lucky you might even get to order from Phil in his infamous little hat. It's a mom & pop type place that specializes in great handmade coffees and teas. Yes! Even the tea I had was yummy and they don't charge extra if you want to add milk, soy or sugar. Also I love LOVE the Vegan Blueberry doughnuts (a little dense but still love 'em).
Warning! If you can't handle an intense caffeine high then go for some black tea (or go down the street to Tartine). This really is Crack coffee.
author: Anica S.

description: Yummiest hot chocolate I've ever had.  I like mine pretty light and not too sweet, and the bittersweet cocoa powder used here is perfect.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Just went here last night and the entire experience was fantastic!! 

I've been to the Philz in the Mission once to get a coffee but this time a bunch of guys sitting outside told me that I just had to try their Chai. So I got a chai and my boyfriend got a coffee (divide and conquer, hey?!) 

I wanted him to try the creamy sugary goodness that only Philz knows how to create but he likes his coffee black. (oy). The guy working (so sorry I didn't get your name!) was SUPER DUPER helpful and enthusiastic (as was the girl working, too) he let him try the coffee black and then split the cup into two cups so half could stay black and the other half could be the famous Philz mix. How nice is that?! I think the coffee flavor was "Red" something... anyways, it was DELICIOUS. 

But the chai! Holy goodness the chai!! The girl who made it must be blessed by the flavor-creation gods! 

Go here. Be friendly and tell them you want their opinion on what to get and they will totally be into it. 

An awesome! Awesome!! coffee-chai experience!
author: Heather W.

description: I LOVE this place!!  The service is excellent, they are super nice!  I just tried the iced mint mojito coffee and it's changed my life! It's so delicious, and I'm hooked!  I want one right now! :)
author: Kelly R.

description:
Philz on 18th is still by far the best!  The staff that brew and make the coffee do make a difference .  'I live by the one on 4th and Berry and it's hit or miss.  It's the first initial taste that wakes those taste buds.  I used to drink the coffee and one day decided to try Philz Green Tea, it was over. I'm hooked.  
1 lg Green Tea triple poured with honey, and cream.  Woot Woot.. they'll know who it is. Nice job guys.
author: Nerdy G.

description:
This is my favorite coffee in the Bay Area.  The Ambrosia coffee with honey....yes I said honey...is possibly the best coffee I have EVER had.  The barista suggested the honey and now I am hooked...he was like "really...you have to trust me..."  Trust is the key to a long intimate relationship, which is hard to find in the Castro :)

The only thing I can say negative is regarding the wide selection of vegan doughnuts (without nonvegan options)....I know that vegans need doughnuts too...but do they need such a variety?  Do we all need to be eating the vegan doughnuts?
author: Michael P.

description:
I moved away from the Bay Area, and I miss Philz.  I have tried to replicate it, but it is a lot of work to get close, then have it "not quite Philz".  So I drink my ordinary, decent coffee in Austin and pine a bit.

A trip to Philz is a part of every SF visit.  Phil is warm and genuine, and I am shocked when he remembers me from the early days.  I wish I could recommend a certain drink, but it is always, "John, let me make you something."  Whatever he makes up that day is some variation on the Philz theme, and it rocks.  In a culture of "triple short half-caf skim no-foam diet vanilla lattes", this is a place where it is OK to let them make you something with love.
author: John E.

description: The sooo good is SOOO GOOD. I'm not sure how they manage to balance the cream/sugar to perfection but damn do I love it. Super friendly too. They need a fake bulldog webcam to capture all the hilarity that is the lifelike beast out front.
author: Cori W.

description:
The coffee is downright ambrosial. Meaning Philz coffee is so delicious, it is worth of the GODS.

People that work there are cool - if you haven't been before or you're not a huge coffee fan, they pepper you with questions about your preferences and then brew you up two different cups of joe.

Wow.
author: Krissy M.

description:
I've had turkish coffee in turkey, espresso in italy, and an orange mocha frappuccino in zoolander. I didn't think there were any new coffee experiences left! 

My friend Rodney took me to Philz. Philz is drip coffee at espresso prices and a taste to die for. I got the turkish with cream and sugar. They grind the coffee, put it in a filter and pour hot water through into a cup - just for you. It had some body to it! I was really impressed. I think I've found my new favorite coffee.
author: Colin N.

description:
Waiting for you coffee to be prepared can be agonizing for the serious caffeine-addict, but the wait is worth it...the stuff is fabulous.

Weirdly, they changed all the names of all the coffees from cities to Classical composers. Manhattan became Mozart and the like. How is a pre-caffeine person meant to remember such things?
author: Hywel J.

description:
MMMM......I loved living across the street from this little slice of heaven.
The lines can be prohibitively long if you're in a rush in the morning, and definitely expect to wait on the weekends. Plan ahead.
Its also $cash$ only.
That being said, some of the most delicious frothy coffee yumminess I've tasted to date. I especially like Jacob's Wunderbar & their Turkish/Arabic blends. Spend some time reading about the other coffees behind the counter, the Peruvian blend (can't remember specific name) was a big hit with Mom.
After a few regular visits, they could make my coffee perfectly--just like your drink at the neighborhood bar replete with a mint sprig.
(I love an accouterment in my drink!)

Edit: I went yesterday and they've expanded their menu. At first I was afraid, then he whipped up something 'special' for me and I had a most productive afternoon.
LOVE.
author: Claire S.

description:
I like them. I really do. I wish they brewed coffee with less acid and more smooth sweet buttery flavor like a moca-java but it's a preference thing and their house blends uses ethopian and/or french which makes a strong bold slightly bitter flavored coffee. They brew it right it's just thier bean preference. But what I like about  them is that they are nice and friendly and let you lurk forever without having that feeling someone is watching you and waiting for you to get out of thier shop. They make a mean mint tea with hand crushed fresh mint.

Next door laundry place is SPOTLESS. I have never seen such a nice laundry. They have the cleanest urinal I have ever seen. It's so amazing it's worth a look in their loo.
author: Kitten M.

description:
i LOVE Philz. the coffee is the best in the city. period.

i just wish the ordering system wasn't such a clusterf&*k. it may just be that people in San Francisco don't know how to queue but whenever any of the Philz locations is the least bit crowded it is super confusing on where the ordering line is versus the paying line versus the i-am-wating-for-my- coffee line.
author: Paul C.

description: Same golden swill as the other locations, but significantly smaller location. Significantly! Particularly since the Van Ness location recently expanded their boundaries.
author: Ken L.

description: What can I say about Philz that everyone else hasn't said. Jacob's brew is the best hands down in my opinion. The coffee is a little bit on the pricey side for me, but it is good to treat yourself to deliciousness every once in a while :)
author: Minh V.

description: Nothing new to tell, but since these fine folks take care of me every day and make the best coffee I've ever had, needed to do my part to erase their half star deficiency.  If ever a business deserved five stars it is this one.  If you like the best coffee ever and really nice people, you will like this place.  If you like bad coffee and mean people you won't.
author: Daniel P.

description:
Awesome coffee. We were walking around Castro and needed a pick-me-up. I remembered there was a Philz in the area and decided to (finally) check them out. Went to this one and the staff was very helpful in picking out a coffee just for our tastes. We found a place to sit outside in the sun and all was good.

I highly recommend this place and can't wait to go back.
author: Rich M.

description:
what a treat for me! i'm from portland and i love my coffee! so when i found out about this place. so they brew each cup individually and make it  it to order. the staff is helpful to explain what you need .

i was told to get the filtered soul with cream, sugar and fresh mint. it was divine! love the addition of the mint is great. 

this is a must if are in san francisco

oh and try the donuts...the blueberry is my favorite!
author: Megan L.

description:
I wrote a much longer review for the 24th St. original Philz but I actually spend much more time at this Castro location because I live closer to it. Just to note: I live in the Sunset and I'll still drive out to the Castro just to get a cup of coffee here. That says a lot, especially since I have literally 5 different cafes (actually 6 now that I think about it) within 5 minutes walking distance of my apartment and most days, I'd rather get in a car and drive to get a cup at Philz.

B/t the two, the Castro location has been, in my opinion, just a little less consistent in terms of the quality of the coffee. As I noted in the other review, the barista does make a difference even if the coffee making system is essentially the same but it's the small things that separate good from great. 

If Phil's son is working at 18th that day, you can expect a pretty solid cup but for example, I got an iced coffee the other day, served by a woman, which was surprisingly bad. Usually, they make the coffee hot, sugar and cream it, THEN pour it over ice. She sugared the coffee cold and as you might imagine, the sugar all fell to the bottom so that the top sips were bitter and the end of the cup was far too sweet. That has been the only time I've ever gotten a bad cup of coffee there. 

Added bonus: free wi-fi and pretty easy parking (at least for the Castro).
author: Oliver W.

description:
A friend and I came to Philz after finding our way to Castro while almost completely clueless about where we were, with no maps or knowledge of where we actually wanted to go.  All we really knew was that we wanted some damn good coffee after freezing in the wind and walking around aimlessly. And, that is most definitely what we got :) .. a nice, warm, perfectly caffeineted mocha.  The two guys working were super nice and friendly and even gave us directions/suggestions of where to go that were really helpful.  Plus, each cup is hand-made and all the roasts were personally perfected by Phil himself (apparently).  
I just really wish that there were one in LA, because I would gladly go back to get away from the usual cup of coffee made by some college student who just wants to be paid minimum wage at a commercially owned place.. it's just not the same! Mmm. I wish i had one now.
author: Kim S.

description: checking off another philz.  more than half were getting the mint mojito coffee.
author: Rob C.

description:
I have never wanted to be one of those people who needs coffee to function every morning, so I try to limit my coffee consumption to the weekend.  The ONLY coffee I will drink here is Philz.  Philz coffee is the most delicious crack attack.  Knowing that Mr. Jaber spent years perfecting his tesora blend makes it even that much better.  The lack of 'tude in the place is delightful as well.  When we are having one of those freakish 70 degree days in the middle of "winter," one of my favorite weekend activities is to buy a cup of Philz and stroll over to Duboce Park, which has one of the highest concentrations of cute dogs per square foot around.  Once we saw a tiny Pomeranian wearing a soccer outfit.  It was so ridiculous that I don't think the owner even minded that we found it hysterical.

But I digress.  Philz consistently wows me with the quality of coffee and genuinely friendly service.  If you have never been you MUST go.  Now my only question is, why the hell is that Starbucks a block away so damn crowded??
author: Leona K.

description:
It was a cold, stormy night in San Francisco.  I took refuge in the cozy, cramped coffeeshop of Philz.

I resigned to a corner, cuddling my warm cup of heated milk.  So soothing, so mild, so smooth.

Wait. I ordered chai.  Chai.  You know, that spicy, flavorful Indian tea made with masala?

Minus one star for the blandest Chai I've ever tasted.  Otherwise, they do have amazing coffee, refer to the reviews below for details.
author: Maia B.

description: I really hate coffee, but this place for some reason makes me want to drink it. they also make a delicious chai tea. So nice, especially on a cold day. I love the care that goes into every cup, very fancy great spot!
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
Best. Coffee. Ever.  

Super nice and not condescending about selling me decaf.  Best decaf I've ever had too.

Tesora always seems to be on sale in December, which is great for gifting.
author: S S.

description:
Awww man!  The first time I took a sip of Philz Tesora with a mint leaf in it......I am salivating just at the thought of it!  It's better than sex is all I can say!  My friend took me to the original Philz on Mission but whenever I come back to visit, I go to this location cuz it's closer to home.

I have YET to find a coffee house here in NYC that offers the creamy, full-bodied flavor with the mint twist.  I've gone to a couple of Mediterranean restaurants and ordered their mint coffee hoping with all my heart it'd taste like Philz but....in the end, my quest continues....

When Phil's there, I am even more delighted cuz i KNOW it's gonna come out tasting like the first time I had it!  There has been times when someone else made it that it didn't taste as good but, still one of the best cup of Joe's I've tasted to date!  

I'd do ANYTHING including trading my first born for a cup of Philz Tesora coffee everyday!
author: Soozie H.

description:
Philz.  The coffee is smoky and dense.  You either like it or you don't.  Lots of people like it but I didn't.  At first.  Then I discovered the mocha.  Yum! And then the black tea, which you wouldn't think they could make taste that good but somehow it does.  How phil?  Then, the lighter brews of coffee like the greater alarm.  Super caffeinated and taste-wise more to my liking than the darker ones. But very very caffeinated!  Not for the feint of heart troubled ones.

So throw in all that plus the tasty pastries, vegan cookies, and super nice, cultishly nice, suspiciously nice, how can you be that nice at like 7:30 am are you a robot nice? personnel and yeah, five stars.  Plus Phil himself is often seen puttering about the place which for some reason for me makes it seem all that much nicer.

Well 6 months or so later I still like philz but you know, I have to downgrade them a star to 4.  Why?  I've had a few cups of coffee that were real stinkers.  I mean dishwater stinkers!  Not sure why this happens, maybe it's the particular barrista or something  but if you like philz and get your coffee made with cream try this: order it with milk, or black and see how tasty it is.
author: David B.

description:
This places has some crazy coffee choices so I was overwhelmed when I first went there. The staff was more than willing to "experiment" with (on?) me by offering all sorts of suggestions, figuring out what my tastes are and building what I can only call a very personalized cup of coffee. 

The coffee was out of this world. Luckily, I had my laptop and they have free wifi so I got to enjoy it to the fullest. I will attempt to go there as often as possible, because coffee is how I survive and good coffee is something that I truly appreciate.

This place is definitely worth a detour!
author: Dumitru E.

description:
I would give these guys and gals five stars because the place rocks, they make the best cup, they know their shiz, but the flow of traffic is a nightmare, patience daniellson! 

They know their coffee and turned me onto my new favorite Red Sea, which is strong and from yemen.  I buy a bag of it every two weeks or so, it's priced good too.

They hand drip brew everything and it's so damn good and potent, but like I said, busy as hell, bad layout to pay and always crowded, but I still go and still will go and like to sit across the street on some random steps and trip on the castro peeps. 

Go philz, you are the shizzle!
author: Mike R.

description:
It's like being in Amsterdam, but with coffee in the coffeshops and not weed.  

I was on my way to Tornado,  a bit stoned,  and decided that I needed a little go-go juice.  Cross the street to 'Bucks?  Nah...let's try a new place so I can get my Yelp on!  I am so glad I found this place.

I asked for a, "medium...no a large coffee..."  I was then assaulted with, "you want a medium roast, large coffee?"   "Uh, no, I am not that picky, I just want a large coffee, you choose the roast."  Who the fuck gets picky with degree of roast at 3 on a Saturday?  I guess Philz customers, because there is a board with about 30 different coffees behind the counter.  YOU GET TO CHOOSE YOUR ROAST!!!  I was overwhelmed (stoned) and told the coffee guy so.  (Barrista my ass, but another day, another review.)  He offered a selection, I accepted and it was ground fresh and hot water poured over it in a very European fashion.  "Cream, sugar?"  "Yes please."  He measured the perfect cream and sugar to coffee ratio and away I went.

WITH THE BEST CUP OF COFFEE THAT I HAVE EVER HAD.

The end.
author: Tony A.

description: Divine. I like light roasts and switch between the Sooooo Good and Canopy of Heaven flavors, light cream light sugar and it is perfect.--a real treat.  The SOMA locale is better if you want to set up shop with a book while the Castro is a bit too small to stick around and hang out.
author: Elana R.

description:
Situated across the street from the Samovar Tea House (Home of the $10 Tofu Block), Philz' second location provides another great stop on the 18th Street promenade of deliciousness.  

The "delicious" here is of the sipping variety and that would be the coffee: brewed one cup at a time and professionally sugared and creamed behind the counter (just like they do at Dunkin Donuts).         I get the cream and sugar (they do have Splenda for those of you who are into that) and end up with a sweet, frothy cup of some of the strongest coffee I've had, so strong it may be perhaps a worthy "stepdown" for any of the circuit boys in the neighborhood looking for ways to wean off "Tina" but still feel perky.

I've tried a number of the brews they offer, and wanted to add a  special mention to the "Philharmonic Wow" as I noticed that a sprinkling of herbs was added to the grounds.  I asked what the herbs were and was told that they were the "wow."  Well, OK! They did add a nice enhanced flavor to the brew, as does the fresh mint sprig topped on the cup at the end (just don't look at the sprig later as the heat wilts it away). 

The ambience of the small shop, while a major step up from when this location was a pathetic "Royal Ground" for a month, is still a little uneven.   There are a number of comfy couches, though not a lot of tables.  The music is all right, but repeats after an hour.  And they should really turn off the two fluorescent lamps in the back corner.  But I have indeed found it a peaceful place to work and drink a tasty, rich, thick cup of Joe worth yelping about.
author: Trent B.

description:
this coffee is yummy.  when i visited my sister last weekend, we woke up super early to go shopping.  we were in dire need for some good coffee so we had to stop here.  since it was my first time, the guy helped me pick out the perfect coffee for me.  all i needed to say was, "strong...size large...medium cream and sugar" and i was set.  this is not your typical starbucks/peets with all of the fru-fru flavored coffee drinks.  this is REAL coffee made simply with cream and sugar-that's it.  they top off the coffee with a mint leaf which just enhanced the flavor of the coffee.  the dark roast which was necessary for 7am in the morning woke me up right away and i was ready to shop til i dropped!

i also got some coffee to go home with.  it's a medium roast called filtered sole and it is soooooooo gooooood!
author: Lindsey A.

description:
Philz is SOOOO GOOD 
and that's what I order every time a large Soo Good 
best coffee in the city 
great service as well
author: Lindsey T.

description:
I've been to the one on 24th street a couple of times, but always with a friend who would order for me.  I walked into this one and looked at the menu with a blank stare usually reserved for the lunch menu in a foreign country.  So when the hot hot mc hottie girl behind the counter asked me if she could make me something off menu all I could do was gulp and say... yes please.

Unfortunately I was too tongue tied to ask for a small.  The rich creamy cardamom flavored coffee was so good I couldn't stop drinking it and nearly suffered fatal caffeine poisoning.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description: Best coffee in town and I'm addicted thanks to my roommate. If there's no line (which is rare), it's pretty quick but it's all hand brewed coffee so expect to wait to order and get your cup of joe. Probably the best hand brewed coffee in the city.
author: David R.

description: Hands down the best cup of coffee I have ever had. The flavor was amazing. I would recommend going out of your way for a cup.
author: Nichole L.

description: We were in town for a few nights and I stopped by here at least 3 times!  LOVE LOVE LOVE it.  Tantalizing Turkish all the way. Please come to Chicago Philz! We do not have single cup joints here!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This place is great!
When I visit my sister who lives in the castro area, I was so pleased to find this place walking distance from her house.  It is unlike any coffee I have ever had.  These people are like coffee bartenders!  They make your drink to order... they grind the beans and brew your individual cup.  My favorites were Jacob's Wonderbar and Mocha Tesora... and, if you're a black coffee drinker like myself... this is one of those places you should treat yourself to cream & sugar.  They make it perfect (their coffee is quite strong!) Just trust them.  
I walked in and told them I'd never been there before, I wasn't familiar with their menu... and they will ask your preferences on coffees and create the perfect cup for you.  Its amazing - and I really like the little mint leaf they float on top.  
Don't pass this place up - they're truly amazing and the people who work here are very helpful..  you don't feel overwhelmed.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Ohhh turkish coffee is yum yum dark rich and smooth......made/brewed by the individual cup, and the chai is also lovely and nutmeg induced
many many many other coffees to choose from, and prices are reasonable.

the interior is homey and comfortable with couches (watch out sometimes Phil is asleep on one), tables to study or work on, and huge plants that make it seem like a jungle. 

altogether i find that anyone i take here is a fan for life, and when i feel like i need a quick pick-me-up i head here first.
author: Rachel R.

description:
What I like best about Philz, in addition to what others say in the glowing reviews, is that there is always a coffee that meets my mood. Dark and gloomy - Turkish. Light and happy - Philharmonic. Not feeling sugary and nice - hold the sugar. Hate mint and cream - no problem. If you go in and just speak your mind - "I am in a light and happy mood and just need a little caffeine to top of my day" - the experts who man the counter will find a coffee for you. And ask if you like it, and I have witnessed them make a different coffee if what they have served up isn't to the taster's liking.

I don't think it's expensive for the quality of coffee, excellent service, individually brewed and a lovely piece of fresh organic mint on top. If you want cheap and quick, 7/11 is across the street.

My only "wish" is that their website listed all the variations of coffee one can order in the store with a brief description so that each evening I can ponder what my fix will be in the morning. And the donuts - too good!
author: Karin S.

description:
I love Philz like no other coffee place around. I adore custom brewed cups and every time I'm there I feel completely taken care of. They are charming and sweet and the coffee makes me swoon! 

I have super high standards for coffee...they rock my socks.
author: Sasha M.

description: After posting my review last week, I received a prompt reply from Lily from Philz. It is nice to see that they take customer feedback seriously and without offense, and that they really do strive to appease customers who have had a less-than-ideal experience. Kudos to her, and I have faith that she and the Philz team will diligently work to make the improvements I suggested. Thanks Lily!
author: Mike H.

description: The mocha was perfectly sweet & chocolaty.  The French puff cheese thing was a delight to put in my mouth, although it could have been heated more thoroughly...  :)
author: Tyler G.

description:
Have you ever tasted coffee that didn't taste like coffee at all?  March your ass up the counter, put down a five dollar bill and ask for a cup of the Philarmonica, a cardamom-infused coffee that is absolutely scrumtrulescent!  For most coffee drinkers that abstain from tossing back shots of espresso-- think coffee house flip cup, (eek!)... this cup of coffee may yield a motivating coffee high. 

The bathroom out back is amazingly clean, in case your cup of coffee inspires more than just feelings of content and motivation.   Well done Philz!
author: Stanley E.

description:
Delicious coffee, but totally makes me CRASH every time.
I even crashed on a decaf!
author: marnie m.

description:
Oh, Philz. I heart you.

Your baristas are always super friendly (and not in a fake way), your coffee is delicious and smooth and did i mention yum?, and I could just sit at one of your tables chatting and people watching for hours. And according to the sign in front of your counter, you have free wifi too, so I'll have to check that out next time.

If only you were a little bit closer. So during the week, I resort to drinking the coffee in the office. But on the weekend, you're worth a little trek. 

Just one thing: WOW on the caffeine. I had a small coffee the other day around 1 pm and was still jittery nearly eight hours later. Not sure if that's impressive or scary.
author: Tara B.

description:
Pre Philz:
Like a Medici immune to poison
from a thousand doses, I scoff
at caff.

Post Philz:
strangely euphoric.  It's 3am,
and I'm twitching like a meth head
banned from Walgreens. 
I toss and turn... could it be?  NAH.

OMG.  My caffeine cherry has been rebroken.
It's that strong.  It's that good.
author: James F.

description:
The coffee is so good you have to go to the bathroom almost immediately.  You know what I mean.

I fear if I had a cigarette at the same time I would probably crap on myself right then and there.

This place ain't no turkey, that's for sure.
author: Jerkey J.

description:
If Blue Bottle is comparable to "good sex", then Philz is undoubtedly an orgy.  

I've spent the majority of my life searching for the besttttt coffee place in the world. Not the "best" place, but the "besttttt" place.  Well, here it is, in all its wonderful glory.

Maybe I'm crazy, but when I go to a cafe, the only thing I want is a damn good cup of coffee.  Well, Phil undoubtedly cares about the quality of his coffee, and it shows in the insane variety and that they have.  Each of their brews is just so incredibly good.  In fact, I'm not even going to do it a disservice by attempting to describe how each of them taste.  Please, stop kidding yourself and just go there.  I don't give a damn what location you go to as long as you get to drink this magnificent wonder.

As an atheist, I once wondered what heaven would be like.  Well, after discovering Philz, I can happily say that heaven would be a cafe that serves their own special coffee blends, and god apparently is a dude named Phil that always rocks a fedora.  : )
author: P. I.

description:
Coffee made to perfection. This place is great. My fiancée and I read the reviews on Yelp! and decided to drop by and check it out.

So many coffee varieties to choose from and each cup of coffee is made per order.

The only downside is the size of the place, but it is San Francisco so I guess it's to be expect. Regardless, don't let it stop you from stopping by and treating yourself to some of the best coffee around.
author: Sean A.

description: This is such a great place. Philz Coffee is so delicious. The Greater Alarm is what I recommend if you're a caffeine addict like myself. The coffee is so fresh. I was also delighted to see they sold vegan pasties as well. The vegan chocolate chip cookie is a must have!
author: Andre B.

description:
Love love love love love love love love love love love love love love.  

I live in freakin' Delaware, and I still dream of Philz Coffee, lovingly handmade, one cup at a time.  I blackmail friends into mailing me beans when they're in town.  I beg my band to play in San Francisco just so I have an excuse to fly there.  

What does that fedora'd man put in the Tesora that makes it so magical?  My friends, I believe it is love.


Oh... And try the baklava.
author: Jill K.

description:
I really dont know what the hub-bub is all about.  Yes, single cup coffee and all these different *wacky* names-- maybe I just wasnt ready to order coffee at philz....

I thought the coffee was good, really good-- but it was more of a latte than a regular drip coffee.  The barista added the milk and sugar for me, so the coffee was a lot sweeter than im use to.

Atmosphere is really nice, I suppose one of these weekend when i want to bum around, i'll hit philz-- but it's kind of a far trek for me :(
author: kate y.

description:
A solid cup'o'joe.  Expensive, but consistently great flavor and strength. I love that the baristas take the time to ask you to taste it and see if it's okay-- they all really seem to take pride in the drinks they make.

The only thing that detracts from this place is the layout. I always experience a cluster of misguided people at the counter. The drink descriptions should be shortened and put higher on the wall-- or there should be hand-held menus to look at.
author: Heather M.

description:
Somehow the barista guru made coffee and honey into a new element. Delicious. I'm still in shock at what a wonderful cup of golden coffee that was. I felt for a moment that I was about to ask her out or something as I was so amorous over her coffee. Thank you barista guru!

Minus one star for high prices :-(
author: J F.

description: I don't really like coffee. But I bought 3 bags of beans for a friend. The staff was very helpful at this Castro location. He had nice earrings. He also gave me free coffee. Was he hitting one me? lol jk I didn't know that if you buy 3 bags of coffee, you get a free cup of coffee. He asked if I wanted small or large. I chose small because I don't like coffee, but wanted to give it another shot. The coffee tasted ok. It was Jacob's something or other. A slight chocolate-y undertone. I like milkshakes better. I would come back here to buy more bags of coffee for gifts cuz the customer service was so great!
author: Timothy L.

description: Iced mint mojito=amazing! I'd take tea over coffee any day, but after having this I'm not sure anymore! If tea and coffee had a baby it'd be an iced mint mojito!!
author: A B.

description:
Easter Sunday I was in here, after losing myself at the bottom of Jameson number 4 the night before.  I needed some lovin and caffeine.  

I walked in, asked for my Jacob's Wonderbar, with cream and sugar.  As I was waiting a confused, perhaps lost woman came in and asked what they meant by one cup at a time.  The very nice barista explained that it meant what it sounded like... they make your coffee one cup at a time... It's a big cup of love.  The woman looked extraordinarily confused, turned around and walked out.  The barista looked sad for a second and sighed, "I guess a cup of love didn't sound very appetizing huh?"

Well... it sounds appetizing to me.  I'll take my love in liquid form on weekend mornings anytime, thank you very much.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Oh dear. Oh dear oh dear oh dear. I am twitching too fast to type. And I had the large Turkish coffee about nine hours ago.

If the decor was better, this place would get five stars.

BZZZZZZZZZ!
author: Fawn F.

description:
I know of few places where I can get a full discussion of Jungian dream analysis and Joseph Campbell theory dropping along with a well crafted, tasty, hand brewed coffee of my choosing in a locale that is both central and hidden, clean, bright and well-populated, relaxed and chill. Centered between a flower shop and laundromat, it goes without saying that along with the stimulating scent of java, Philz smells incredible. 

The guys at Philz do their very brightest best to give you an astounding cup of joe. I had the iced mint mojito caffe just the other day and before I am horsewhipped for my lack of taste, let us just review for a moment. Sweet, light, fresh. None of that crazy thicker-than-motor-oil flavor that Peets will give me and a light buzz. I am a chickie for trying new tastes and this one was definitely a good one.
